awd_titl_txt: CSR: Large: VarSys: Managing Variability in High-Performance Computing Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Exascale high-performance computing (HPC) systems are required to meet the demands of many grand challenges for scientific computing and e-commerce in the 21st century. Variability in these systems is growing intractably and leads to performance loss and energy waste. This project is building the Variability System (VarSys) software framework, grounded in fundamental engineering principles, to enable variability management in large-scale advanced computing systems. The intellectual challenges in this work include determining the extent to which variability can be managed and the tradeoffs that result from such management. The work will demonstrate the use of variability management on large scale systems and cloud infrastructures. 

The continuation of the project will endeavor to create methodologies to establish a community ecosystem to benchmark progress and engage a broader community in this research.  Currently, there are over 25 faculty, staff and students (including 6 women and 2 minority students) participating in the project and more than 200 students have been exposed to system variability in the operating system courses. The project will also create additional compelling videos and other media artifacts to describe the progress and capture the excitement inherent to the research.

Keywords: high-performance computing; statistical and mathematical modeling; variability-performance trade-offs

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The VarSys Project funded dozens of students and their faculty advisors in support of 14 PhD's and about a dozen master's degrees. The resulting collaborative research improves our understanding of performance variability in high-performance systems for applications including data transfer and manipulation to articifical intelligence. Here are some specific contributions of the team over the duration of the project.

ON POPULATION DISTRIBUTIONS: Our work is transformative in nature. A crux of the high-performance and cloud communities is their reliance on standard statistical techniques in experimental systems evaluations. One key finding in the VarSys project is that the assumption of standard population distributions used in nearly all aspects of experimental systems research is statistically incorrect. The impact of these distributions is significant. While this does not discredit past research fully, it calls into question the underlying methodologies we use to evaluate new system designs.

Our hope is that by better understanding these population distributions, we can identify statistical techniques that can enable progress in the face of variability for future advanced computing systems. Still, the potential disruption of these findings means they will be highly controversial initially. 

ON ALGORITHM DEVELOPMENT: Our work resulted in creation of parallel, scalable, algorithmic techniques for prediction and analysis of variability on high-order variables. We have demonstrated the viability of creating solvers that can predict efficiently at extreme scales in the number of variables. This was a hypothesis of our black box approach and required the collaborative expertise of all the systems teams, the statisticians, and the mathematicians. The result is VTMOP: Solver for blackbox multi-obective optimization problems. Additional work incudes a DELAUNEY solver and the software in the ACM mathematical solver library (Collected Algorithms of the ACM at calgo.acm.org.) The new techniques can efficiently model high-order changes in systems configurations for future systems and design parameterization.


MULTI-MODAL DISTRIBUTIONS: We have determined that there are groups of system and application configurations that can be categorized based upon their population distributions. Furthermore, we have been able to determine causality in some cases between the number of modes in a population and the system and application configurations. This is an excellent example of the need for multidisciplinary teams including systems, statistics, and math experts to analyze variability in large-scale systems.


ON VARIABILITY MANAGEMENT: Our results and our high-fidelity experiments demonstrate we can predict variability with enough accuracy to design variability controllers. We found that causality determination should streamline variability controller design. This supports a major thesis of our work and gives us cause to design controllers that are variability aware and use advances from the stats team (e.g., streamlining experiment design) and the math team (e.g., the VTMOPS and DELAUNEY predictors). This could enable a new class of controllers with “variability-awareness” built in.

ON TOOL DEVELOPMENT: The project has resulted in design of three key tools to enable further research. The csgenome database (developed as part of the iLORE project but based on ontologies discovered for this project) is a new tool for users to explore the individual effects of hardware artifacts on performance variability over time. VarViz enables interactive visualization of variability and evaluation of variability predictors in real time. VarSub enables batch submission of variability experiments. Both tools have been tested extensively in-house. Both tools have been released publicly. The first-order potential impact is for others to evaluate the variability of their own systems. Developers may adapt the software for other uses as a second order effect.

ON PEDAGOGY: As promised in the proposal, we were able to stand up a framework to enable students to study variability in coursework and release the results back to our research team for analysis. As we’ve moved into more research-driven questions, we’ve adapted our tools and pedagogy (e.g., video tutorials) to enable broader groups of participants and increase the diversity of our teams. As a result, we include more undergraduates and carve out a tangential project (the CS Genome work) that excites and involves them in an inclusive way where all can meaningfully contribute immediately despite only an initial novice CS background.

ON DIVERSITY, EQUITY, AND INCLUSION: We have pioneered efforts to recruit, train, and retain a diverse cohort of undergraduate and graduate student researchers in computer systems work. The effort involves a number of leadership that includes “safe zones” for students to meet on a weekly basis and mentoring of new students by trained students. The result is a full pipeline of CS systems researchers with 50% women and 25% African American students working on important systems challenges. Select students are recruited for the graduate program (9 with MS degrees, including 1 male African American and 1 female African American). Participation from students identifying as those from underrepresented groups are 3x and 10x department norms for CS women and African American students respectively.
